Figure 3.11 Technology developments in pay and free-to-air TV

column4: •Horizontal – retail rather than operator led – DVR markets developed in many countries, mostly on DTT and satellite
column5: •Widespread across many platforms, high capacity devices available, some with ‘virtual’ VoD

column4: •Limited roll-out by FTA platforms due to complexity
column5: •Large libraries of VoD available (17,000 items on Comcast)
•Many content genres, available for free, subscription or PPV

column2: •TV channels five times picture quality of standard definition digital TV
column4: •Many FTA channels are launching HD not always available on FTA platforms but within pay packages
column5: •HDTV is now a key product for pay to differentiate from FTA.
•Platforms use HD as a marketing tool (DirecTV has 160 channels).

column4: •Most 3DTV channels are available in pay bouquets
column5: •3D is one of the next technical developments in TV viewing

column4: •Given the infancy of 3DTV, few FTA broadcasters have launched services
column5: •Pay providers are launching HD channels, focusing on sports, movies and factual shows

column2: •Deliver  on-demand content to PCs and other devices
column4: •Online catch-up  TV allows FTA  channels to broaden reach, attract new viewers
column5: •Could be seen as a threat to pay TV (cancelled subscriptions)

column4: •Also can generate additional revenue and mitigate piracy
column5: •Some operators using online TV as a ‘value-add’, offering portability of content

column2: •Deliver VoD and other applications  over open internet  (‘over the top’) to TV
column4: •FTA is playing a major role in development of OTT services to PCs and retail devices such as STBs and TVs (YouView and HbbTV) to offer VoD
column5: •Pay operators have been slower to launch OTT (as IPTV and cable have VoD)
•Some satellite platforms see OTT as way of  offering VoD
